actuality.normalized: And God called the dry land Earth, and the gathering together of the waters called He Seas; and God saw that it was good.
And God said: 'Let the earth put forth grass, herb yielding seed, and fruit-tree bearing fruit after its kind, wherein is the seed thereof, upon the earth.' And it was so.
And the earth brought forth grass, herb yielding seed after its kind, and tree bearing fruit, wherein is the seed thereof, after its kind; and God saw that it was good.

entity.description: the third day

actuality.normalized: And God said: 'Let there be lights in the firmament of the heaven to divide the day from the night; and let them be for signs, and for seasons, and for days and years; and let them be for lights in the firmament of the heaven to give light upon the earth.' And it was so.

actuality.normalized: And God made the two great lights: the greater light to rule the day, and the lesser light to rule the night; and the stars.
And God set them in the firmament of the heaven to give light upon the earth, and to rule over the day and over the night, and to divide the light from the darkness; and God saw that it was good.

entity.description: the fourth day

actuality.normalized: And God created the great sea-monsters, and every living creature that creepeth, wherewith the waters swarmed, after its kind, and every winged fowl after its kind; and God saw that it was good.
And God blessed them, saying: 'Be fruitful, and multiply, and fill the waters in the seas, and let fowl multiply in the earth.'

entity.description: the fifth day

actuality.normalized: And God made the beast of the earth after its kind, and the cattle after their kind, and every thing that creepeth upon the ground after its kind; and God saw that it was good.

And God said: 'Let us make man in our image, after our likeness; and let them have dominion over the fish of the sea, and over the fowl of the air, and over the cattle, and over all the earth, and over every creeping thing that creepeth upon the earth.'

entity.description: humankind

female sex

actuality.normalized: And God created man in His own image, in the image of God created He him; male and female created He them.

And God blessed them; and God said unto them: 'Be fruitful, and multiply, and replenish the earth, and subdue it; and have dominion over the fish of the sea, and over the fowl of the air, and over every living thing that creepeth upon the earth.'

And God said: 'Behold, I have given you every herb yielding seed, which is upon the face of all the earth, and every tree, in which is the fruit of a tree yielding seed—to you it shall be for food; and to every beast of the earth, and to every fowl of the air, and to every thing that creepeth upon the earth, wherein there is a living soul, [I have given] every green herb for food.' And it was so.
And God saw every thing that He had made, and, behold, it was very good.

These are the generations of the heaven and of the earth when they were created, in the day that the LORD God made earth and heaven.
No shrub of the field was yet in the earth, and no herb of the field had yet sprung up; for the LORD God had not caused it to rain upon the earth, and there was not a man to till the ground.
But there went up a mist from the earth, and watered the whole face of the ground.

for God doth know that in the day ye eat thereof, then your eyes shall be opened, and ye shall be as God, knowing good and evil.

and the man and his wife hid themselves from the presence of the LORD God amongst the trees of the garden.
And the LORD God called unto the man, and said unto him: 'Where art thou?'
And he said: 'I heard Thy voice in the garden, and I was afraid, because I was naked; and I hid myself.'

And the LORD God said unto the serpent: 'Because thou hast done this, cursed art thou from among all cattle, and from among all beasts of the field; upon thy belly shalt thou go, and dust shalt thou eat all the days of thy life.'

actuality.normalized: And I will put enmity between thee and the woman, and between thy seed and her seed; they shall bruise thy head, and thou shalt bruise their heel.'
Unto the woman He said: 'I will greatly multiply thy pain and thy travail; in pain thou shalt bring forth children; and thy desire shall be to thy husband, and he shall rule over thee.'

And unto Adam He said: 'Because thou hast hearkened unto the voice of thy wife, and hast eaten of the tree, of which I commanded thee, saying: Thou shalt not eat of it; cursed is the ground for thy sake; in toil shalt thou eat of it all the days of thy life.'
Thorns also and thistles shall it bring forth to thee; and thou shalt eat the herb of the field.
In the sweat of thy face shalt thou eat bread, till thou return unto the ground; for out of it wast thou taken; for dust thou art, and unto dust shalt thou return.

aspect.normalized: And the man called his wife's name Eve; because she was the mother of all living.

Therefore the LORD God sent him forth from the garden of Eden, to till the ground from whence he was taken.
So He drove out the man;

actuality.normalized: And in process of time it came to pass, that Cain brought of the fruit of the ground an offering unto the LORD.
And Abel, he also brought of the firstlings of his flock and of the fat thereof; and the LORD had respect unto Abel and to his offering;
but unto Cain and to his offering He had not respect.

aspect.normalized: And Cain was very wroth, and his countenance fell.

actuality.normalized: And the LORD said unto Cain: 'Why art thou wroth? and why is thy countenance fallen? If thou doest well, shall it not be lifted up? and if thou doest not well, sin coucheth at the door; and unto thee is its desire, but thou mayest rule over it.'
And Cain spoke unto Abel his brother. And it came to pass, when they were in the field, that Cain rose up against Abel his brother, and slew him.
And the LORD said unto Cain: 'Where is Abel thy brother?' And he said: 'I know not; am I my brother's keeper?'
And He said: 'What hast thou done? the voice of thy brother's blood crieth unto Me from the ground.'
And now cursed art thou from the ground, which hath opened her mouth to receive thy brother's blood from thy hand.
When thou tillest the ground, it shall not henceforth yield unto thee her strength; a fugitive and a wanderer shalt thou be in the earth.
And Cain said unto the LORD: 'My punishment is greater than I can bear.'

Behold, Thou hast driven me out this day from the face of the land; and from Thy face shall I be hid; and I shall be a fugitive and a wanderer in the earth; and it will come to pass, that whosoever findeth me will slay me.
And the LORD said unto him: 'Therefore whosoever slayeth Cain, vengeance shall be taken on him sevenfold.'

actuality.normalized: In the day that God created man, in the likeness of God made He him; male and female created He them, and blessed them, and called their name Adam, in the day when they were created.
And Adam lived a hundred and thirty years, and begot a son in his own likeness, after his image; and called his name Seth.
And the days of Adam after he begot Seth were eight hundred years; and he begot sons and daughters.
And all the days that Adam lived were nine hundred and thirty years; and he died.
And Seth lived a hundred and five years, and begot Enosh.
And Seth lived after he begot Enosh eight hundred and seven years, and begot sons and daughters.
And all the days of Seth were nine hundred and twelve years; and he died.

And Kenan lived after he begot Mahalalel eight hundred and forty years, and begot sons and daughters.
And all the days of Kenan were nine hundred and ten years; and he died.

And Enoch walked with God, and he was not; for God took him.

actuality.normalized: And I, behold, I do bring the flood of waters upon the earth, to destroy all flesh, wherein is the breath of life, from under heaven; every thing that is in the earth shall perish.

entity.description: divine covenant to be established with Noah

actuality.normalized: But I will establish My covenant with thee; and thou shalt come into the ark, thou, and thy sons, and thy wife, and thy sons' wives with thee.
Of every living thing of all flesh, two of every sort shalt thou bring into the ark, to keep them alive with thee; they shall be male and female.
Of the fowl after their kind, and of the cattle after their kind, of every creeping thing of the ground after its kind, two of every sort shall come unto thee, to keep them alive.
And take thou unto thee of all food that is eaten, and gather it to thee; and it shall be for food for thee, and for them.
Thus did Noah; according to all that God commanded him, so did he.
And the LORD said unto Noah: 'Come thou and all thy house into the ark; for thee have I seen righteous before Me in this generation.'

entity.description: animals designated clean
animals not designated clean

actuality.normalized: Of every clean beast thou shalt take to thee seven and seven, each with his mate; and of the beasts that are not clean two and two, each with his mate; of the fowl also of the air, seven and seven, male and female; to keep seed alive upon the face of all the earth.
For yet seven days, and I will cause it to rain upon the earth forty days and forty nights; and every living substance that I have made will I blot out from off the face of the earth.
And Noah did according unto all that the LORD commanded him.

aspect.normalized: Noah was six hundred years old when the flood of waters was upon the earth.

actuality.normalized: And Noah went in, and his sons, and his wife, and his sons' wives with him, into the ark, because of the waters of the flood.

Of clean beasts, and of beasts that are not clean, and of fowls, and of every thing that creepeth upon the ground, there went in two and two unto Noah into the ark, male and female, as God commanded Noah.
And it came to pass after the seven days, that the waters of the flood were upon the earth.
In the six hundredth year of Noah's life, in the second month, on the seventeenth day of the month, all the fountains of the great deep were broken up, and the windows of heaven were opened.
And the rain was upon the earth forty days and forty nights.

In the selfsame day entered Noah, and Shem, and Ham, and Japheth, the sons of Noah, and Noah's wife, and the three wives of his sons with them, into the ark; they, and every beast after its kind, and all the cattle after their kind, and every creeping thing that creepeth upon the earth after its kind, and every fowl after its kind, every bird of every sort.

And they went in unto Noah into the ark, two and two of all flesh wherein is the breath of life; and they that went in, went in male and female of all flesh, as God commanded him; and the LORD shut him in.
And the flood was forty days upon the earth; and the waters increased, and bore up the ark, and it was lifted up above the earth.
And the waters prevailed, and increased greatly upon the earth; and the ark went upon the face of the waters.

And the waters prevailed exceedingly upon the earth; and all the high mountains that were under the whole heaven were covered. Fifteen cubits upward did the waters prevail; and the mountains were covered.

And all flesh perished that moved upon the earth, both fowl, and cattle, and beast, and every swarming thing that swarmeth upon the earth, and every man; all in whose nostrils was the breath of the spirit of life, whatsoever was in the dry land, died.

And He blotted out every living substance which was upon the face of the ground, both man, and cattle, and creeping thing, and fowl of the heaven; and they were blotted out from the earth; and Noah only was left, and they that were with him in the ark.

aspect.normalized: the waters prevailed upon the earth a hundred and fifty days.

actuality.normalized: And God remembered Noah, and every living thing, and all the cattle that were with him in the ark; and God made a wind to pass over the earth, and the waters assuaged.
The fountains also of the deep and the windows of heaven were stopped, and the rain from heaven was restrained.
And the waters returned from off the earth continually; and after the end of a hundred and fifty days the waters decreased.

entity.description: mountains upon which the ark rested

actuality.normalized: And the ark rested upon the mountains of Ararat.
And the waters decreased continually until the tenth month; in the tenth month, on the first day of the month, were the tops of the mountains seen.

entity.description: a window which Noah had made in the ark
a raven sent forth by Noah
a dove sent forth by Noah

actuality.normalized: And it came to pass at the end of forty days, that Noah opened the window of the ark which he had made.
And he sent forth a raven, and it went to and fro, until the waters were dried up from off the earth.
And he sent forth a dove from him, to see if the waters were abated from off the face of the ground.

But the dove found no rest for the sole of her foot, and she returned unto him to the ark, for the waters were on the face of the whole earth; and he put forth his hand, and took her, and brought her in unto him into the ark.
And he stayed yet other seven days; and again he sent forth the dove out of the ark.
And the dove came in to him at eventide; and, lo, in her mouth an olive-leaf freshly plucked; so Noah knew that the waters were abated from off the earth.
And he stayed yet other seven days; and sent forth the dove; and she returned not again unto him any more.

In the six hundred and first year, in the first month, the first day of the month, the waters were dried up from off the earth; and Noah removed the covering of the ark, and looked, and behold, the face of the ground was dried.

aspect.normalized: In the second month, on the twenty-seventh day of the month, the earth was dry.

actuality.normalized: And God spoke unto Noah, saying: 'Go forth from the ark, thou, and thy wife, and thy sons, and thy sons' wives with thee.'

'Bring forth with thee every living thing of all flesh, both fowl, and cattle, and every creeping thing that creepeth upon the earth; that they may swarm in the earth, and be fruitful, and multiply upon the earth.'

And Noah went forth, and his sons, and his wife, and his sons' wives with him; every beast, every creeping thing, and every fowl, whatsoever moveth upon the earth, after their families, went forth out of the ark.

entity.description: altar built by Noah to the LORD

actuality.normalized: And Noah builded an altar unto the LORD; and took of every clean beast, and of every clean fowl, and offered burnt-offerings on the altar.

And the LORD smelled the sweet savour; and the LORD said in His heart: 'I will not again curse the ground any more for man's sake; for the imagination of man's heart is evil from his youth; neither will I again smite any more every thing living, as I have done.'

entity.description: divine decree that seasons and day-night shall not cease while the earth remains

actuality.normalized: 'While the earth remaineth, seedtime and harvest, and cold and heat, and summer and winter, and day and night shall not cease.'
And God blessed Noah and his sons, and said unto them: 'Be fruitful and multiply, and replenish the earth.'

'And the fear of you and the dread of you shall be upon every beast of the earth, and upon every fowl of the air, and upon all wherewith the ground teemeth, and upon all the fishes of the sea: into your hand are they delivered.'

entity.description: authorization to eat every moving living thing as food, as the green herb
prohibition against eating flesh with its life, its blood
requirement of lifeblood and principle of retributive justice for shedding human blood

actuality.normalized: 'Every moving thing that liveth shall be for food for you; as the green herb have I given you all. Only flesh with the life thereof, which is the blood thereof, shall ye not eat.'

'And surely your blood of your lives will I require; at the hand of every beast will I require it; and at the hand of man, even at the hand of every man's brother, will I require the life of man. Whoso sheddeth man's blood, by man shall his blood be shed; for in the image of God made He man.'
'And you, be ye fruitful, and multiply; swarm in the earth, and multiply therein.'

entity.description: divine covenant established with Noah, his descendants, and every living creature
the token/sign of the covenant set in the cloud

actuality.normalized: And God spoke unto Noah, and to his sons with him, saying: 'As for Me, behold, I establish My covenant with you, and with your seed after you; and with every living creature that is with you... neither shall all flesh be cut off any more by the waters of the flood; neither shall there any more be a flood to destroy the earth.'

And God said: 'This is the token of the covenant which I make between Me and you and every living creature that is with you, for perpetual generations: I have set My bow in the cloud, and it shall be for a token of a covenant between Me and the earth.'

'And it shall come to pass, when I bring clouds over the earth, and the bow is seen in the cloud, that I will remember My covenant ... and the waters shall no more become a flood to destroy all flesh.'
'And the bow shall be in the cloud; and I will look upon it, that I may remember the everlasting covenant between God and every living creature of all flesh that is upon the earth.'
And God said unto Noah: 'This is the token of the covenant which I have established between Me and all flesh that is upon the earth.'

actuality.normalized: They said one to another: 'Come, let us make brick, and burn them thoroughly.' And they had brick for stone, and slime had they for mortar.
And they said: 'Come, let us build us a city, and a tower, with its top in heaven, and let us make us a name; lest we be scattered abroad upon the face of the whole earth.'
And the LORD came down to see the city and the tower, which the children of men builded.

And the LORD said: 'Behold, they are one people, and they have all one language; and this is what they begin to do; and now nothing will be withholden from them, which they purpose to do. Come, let us go down, and there confound their language, that they may not understand one another's speech.'
So the LORD scattered them abroad from thence upon the face of all the earth; and they left off to build the city.
Therefore was the name of it called Babel; because the LORD did there confound the language of all the earth; and from thence did the LORD scatter them abroad upon the face of all the earth.

The LORD said unto Abram: 'Go from your country, kindred, and father's house to the land that I will show you; I will make of you a great nation, bless you, make your name great—be a blessing; I will bless those who bless you and curse him that curses you; in you shall all families of the earth be blessed.'
Abram went as the LORD had spoken to him, and Lot went with him; Abram was seventy-five years old when he departed out of Haran.
Abram took Sarai his wife, Lot his brother's son, all their substance, and the persons they had acquired in Haran; they went to go into the land of Canaan, and into the land of Canaan they came.

Near entering Egypt, Abram said to Sarai his wife that she was very fair; he asked her to say she was his sister so it might be well with him and his life be spared for her sake.

actuality.normalized: When Abram entered Egypt, the Egyptians saw that Sarai was very fair; the princes of Pharaoh saw her and praised her to Pharaoh, and the woman was taken into Pharaoh's house.
Pharaoh dealt well with Abram for her sake, and Abram had sheep, oxen, he-asses, men-servants, maid-servants, she-asses, and camels.
The LORD plagued Pharaoh and his house with great plagues because of Sarai, Abram's wife.
Pharaoh called Abram and rebuked him for saying, 'She is my sister', returned Sarai, and commanded men concerning Abram; they sent him away with his wife and all that he had.
Abram went up out of Egypt, he and his wife and all that he had, and Lot with him, into the South.

aspect.normalized: Abram was very rich in cattle, in silver, and in gold.

Abram said to Lot that there be no strife between them or their herdmen, for they are brethren; he urged separation with choice of left or right.

actuality.normalized: Abimelech and Phicol speak to Abraham, acknowledging that God is with him, and request an oath of fair dealing across generations.
Abraham swears and reproves Abimelech over a well that Abimelech's servants seized.
Abimelech pleads ignorance of the matter.
Abraham gives Abimelech sheep and oxen and they make a covenant; Abraham sets seven ewe-lambs apart as a witness that he dug the well.
The place is called Beer-sheba because there they both swore; a covenant is made at Beer-sheba; Abimelech and Phicol return to the land of the Philistines.
Abraham plants a tamarisk-tree in Beer-sheba and calls on the name of the LORD, the Everlasting God; he sojourns in the land of the Philistines many days.

actuality.normalized: God tests Abraham, commanding him to take his son Isaac to the Land of Moriah and offer him as a burnt-offering on a mountain that God will show.
Abraham rises early, prepares, and travels with two young men and Isaac to the place God spoke of; on the third day he sees the place afar off.
Abraham tells his young men to remain while he and the lad go to worship and return.
Abraham lays the wood on Isaac, takes fire and knife; they go together. Isaac asks about the lamb, and Abraham answers that God will provide Himself the lamb.
At the appointed place Abraham builds an altar, arranges the wood, binds Isaac, and lays him on the altar.
Abraham stretches out his hand and takes the knife to slay his son, but the Angel of the LORD calls from heaven, stopping him and acknowledging his fear of God.
Abraham sees a ram caught by its horns in a thicket and offers it as a burnt-offering instead of his son.
Abraham names the place Adonai-jireh; it is said, 'In the mount where the LORD is seen.'

The Angel of the LORD calls to Abraham a second time, delivering God's oath: blessing and multiplying his seed like the stars and the sand; his seed will possess the gate of his enemies, and all nations will be blessed in his seed because he obeyed.
Abraham returns to his young men and they go together to Beer-sheba; Abraham dwells at Beer-sheba.

News is told to Abraham: Milcah has borne children to his brother Nahor—Uz, Buz, Kemuel (father of Aram), Chesed, Hazo, Pildash, Jidlaph, and Bethuel; Bethuel begot Rebekah; Reumah, Nahor's concubine, bore Tebah, Gaham, Tahash, and Maacah.

Ephron answered Abraham and said, "My lord, hearken unto me: a piece of land worth four hundred shekels of silver, what is that betwixt me and thee? bury therefore thy dead."
Abraham listened to Ephron and weighed out four hundred shekels of silver, current money with the merchant, to Ephron.

actuality.normalized: Abraham said to his servant, the elder of his house who ruled over all that he had, "Put, I pray thee, thy hand under my thigh."
Abraham said, "I will make thee swear by the LORD, the God of heaven and the God of the earth, that thou shalt not take a wife for my son from the daughters of the Canaanites among whom I dwell."

entity.description: Isaac is Abraham's son.

actuality.normalized: Abraham instructed his servant, "Go to my country and to my kindred and take a wife for my son Isaac."
The servant said to Abraham, "Peradventure the woman will not be willing to follow me unto this land; must I bring thy son back to the land whence thou camest?"
Abraham said to him, "Beware that thou bring not my son back thither."

Abraham said that the LORD who took him from his father's house and from the land of his nativity, who spoke to him and swore to him, saying, "Unto thy seed will I give this land," will send His angel before the servant and the servant shall take a wife for Isaac from there.
Abraham concluded, "If the woman is not willing to follow thee, then thou shalt be clear from this my oath; only thou shalt not bring my son back thither."
The servant put his hand under the thigh of Abraham his master and swore to him concerning this matter.

actuality.normalized: The servant took ten camels of his master and departed, having all goodly things of his master's in his hand, and went to Aram-naharaim unto the City of Nahor.

entity.description: A fountain/well of water outside the city.

actuality.normalized: He made the camels kneel down outside the city by the well of water at evening, the time when women go out to draw water.
The servant prayed and said, "O LORD, the God of my master Abraham, send me good speed this day and show kindness to my master Abraham."
He said, "Behold, I stand by the fountain of water; and the daughters of the men of the city come out to draw water."

He petitioned, "Let it come to pass that the damsel to whom I shall say, 'Let down thy pitcher that I may drink,' and she shall say, 'Drink, and I will give thy camels drink also,' let the same be she that Thou hast appointed for Thy servant, even for Isaac; and thereby shall I know that Thou hast shown kindness unto my master."

actuality.normalized: Before he had done speaking, Rebekah came out, born to Bethuel the son of Milcah, the wife of Nahor, Abraham's brother, with her pitcher upon her shoulder.

aspect.normalized: The damsel is a virgin.

actuality.normalized: Rebekah went down to the fountain, filled her pitcher, and came up.
The servant ran to meet Rebekah and said, "Give me to drink, I pray thee, a little water of thy pitcher."
Rebekah said, "Drink, my lord," and hastened, let down her pitcher upon her hand, and gave him drink.
When she had done giving him drink, she said, "I will draw for thy camels also, until they have done drinking."
Rebekah hastened, emptied her pitcher into the trough, ran again to the well to draw, and drew for all his camels.
The man looked steadfastly on her, holding his peace, to know whether the LORD had made his journey prosperous or not.

entity.description: A golden ring of half a shekel weight.
Two bracelets for Rebekah's hands, ten shekels weight of gold.

actuality.normalized: When the camels had done drinking, the man took a golden ring of half a shekel weight and two bracelets for her hands of ten shekels weight of gold.
He said, "Whose daughter art thou? tell me, I pray thee. Is there room in thy father's house for us to lodge in?"
Rebekah said, "I am the daughter of Bethuel the son of Milcah, whom she bore unto Nahor."
She said moreover, "We have both straw and provender enough, and room to lodge in."
The man bowed his head and prostrated himself before the LORD.

He said, "Blessed be the LORD, the God of my master Abraham, who has not forsaken His mercy and His truth toward my master; as for me, the LORD has led me in the way to the house of my master's brethren."
The damsel ran and told her mother's house according to these words.

entity.description: Laban is Rebekah's brother.

actuality.normalized: Rebekah had a brother named Laban, and Laban ran out to the man at the fountain.
When Laban saw the ring and the bracelets upon his sister's hands and heard Rebekah's words, he came to the man and found him standing by the camels at the fountain.
Laban said, "Come in, thou blessed of the LORD; wherefore standest thou without? for I have cleared the house, and made room for the camels."
The man came into the house and ungirded the camels; he gave straw and provender for the camels and water to wash his feet and the feet of the men that were with him.
Food was set before him to eat, but he said, "I will not eat, until I have told mine errand," and the host said, "Speak on."
He said, "I am Abraham's servant."
He said, "The LORD hath blessed my master greatly; and he is become great; and He hath given him flocks and herds, and silver and gold, and men-servants and maid-servants, and camels and asses."

actuality.normalized: Sarah, my master's wife, bore a son to Abraham when she was old, and Abraham has given to him all that he has.
Abraham made his servant swear not to take a wife for his son from the daughters of the Canaanites among whom he dwells, but to go to his father's house and kindred to take a wife for his son.

Abraham said the LORD before whom he walks will send His angel with the servant and prosper his way; the servant will take a wife for Abraham's son from his kindred and father's house, and if they do not give her, the servant shall be clear from the oath upon coming to the kindred.
The servant recounts his prayer at the fountain asking the LORD to prosper his way and to identify the appointed woman by her offering water to him and also to his camels.
Before he had finished speaking in his heart, Rebekah came with her pitcher on her shoulder, went down to the fountain, and drew.
He asked Rebekah for a drink; she made haste, let down her pitcher, said, "Drink, and I will give thy camels drink also"; he drank, and she made the camels drink also.
He asked her identity; she said she is the daughter of Bethuel, Nahor's son, whom Milcah bore to him.
He put the ring upon her nose and the bracelets upon her hands.
He bowed and prostrated himself before the LORD and blessed the LORD, acknowledging that he had been led in the right way to take his master's brother's daughter for his master's son.
He requested an answer whether they would deal kindly and truly with his master, or else he would turn to the right or to the left.
Laban and Bethuel answered that the matter proceeds from the LORD and they cannot speak bad or good; they consented that Rebekah be taken as wife for Abraham's son's wife, as the LORD has spoken.
When Abraham's servant heard their words, he bowed himself to the earth unto the LORD.
The servant brought forth jewels of silver, jewels of gold, and raiment and gave them to Rebekah; he also gave precious things to her brother and her mother.
They ate and drank, he and the men with him, and tarried all night; they rose in the morning and he said, "Send me away unto my master."
Her brother and her mother asked that the damsel abide with them a few days, at least ten; after that she shall go.
The servant said not to delay him, seeing the LORD has prospered his way; he asked to be sent away to his master.
They called Rebekah and asked, "Wilt thou go with this man?" and she said, "I will go."
They sent away Rebekah their sister, her nurse, Abraham's servant, and his men.
They blessed Rebekah, saying she should be mother of thousands of ten thousands, and that her seed possess the gate of those who hate them.
Rebekah and her damsels arose, rode upon the camels, followed the man; the servant took Rebekah and went his way.
Isaac came from the way of Beer-lahai-roi; he dwelt in the land of the South.
Isaac went out to meditate in the field at eventide; he lifted up his eyes and saw camels coming.
Rebekah lifted up her eyes and, seeing Isaac, alighted from the camel.
Rebekah asked the servant who the man walking in the field to meet them was; the servant said, "It is my master." She took her veil and covered herself.
The servant told Isaac all the things that he had done.
Isaac brought Rebekah into his mother Sarah's tent; he took Rebekah and she became his wife; he loved her; and Isaac was comforted for his mother.
Abraham took another wife named Keturah.
Keturah bore to Abraham Zimran, Jokshan, Medan, Midian, Ishbak, and Shuah.
Jokshan begot Sheba and Dedan.
The sons of Dedan were Asshurim, Letushim, and Leummim.
The sons of Midian were Ephah, Epher, Hanoch, Abida, and Eldaah.
All these were the children of Keturah.
Abraham gave all that he had unto Isaac.
To the sons of the concubines that Abraham had, Abraham gave gifts and sent them away from Isaac his son, while he yet lived, eastward to the east country.

aspect.normalized: Abraham lived one hundred seventy-five years.

actuality.normalized: Abraham expired and died in a good old age, an old man and full of years, and was gathered to his people.

Isaac and Ishmael his sons buried Abraham in the cave of Machpelah, in the field of Ephron son of Zohar the Hittite, before Mamre; this field Abraham purchased of the children of Heth; there Abraham was buried, and Sarah his wife.
After Abraham's death, God blessed Isaac his son, and Isaac dwelt by Beer-lahai-roi.
These are the generations of Ishmael, Abraham's son, whom Hagar the Egyptian, Sarah's handmaid, bore to Abraham.
The names of the sons of Ishmael according to their generations are: Nebaioth (first-born), Kedar, Adbeel, Mibsam, Mishma, Dumah, Massa, Hadad, Tema, Jetur, Naphish, and Kedem.
These are the sons of Ishmael, their names by their villages and encampments—twelve princes according to their nations.

aspect.normalized: Ishmael lived one hundred and thirty-seven years.

aspect.normalized: Isaac was forty years old when he took Rebekah to be his wife.

actuality.normalized: Isaac took Rebekah, daughter of Bethuel the Aramean of Paddan-aram and sister of Laban the Aramean, to be his wife.
Isaac entreated the LORD for his wife because she was barren; the LORD was entreated of him, and Rebekah his wife conceived.
The children struggled together within Rebekah; she asked, 'If it be so, why do I live?' and she went to inquire of the LORD.
The LORD said to her: Two nations are in thy womb; two peoples shall be separated; one people shall be stronger than the other; and the elder shall serve the younger.
When her days to be delivered were fulfilled, behold, there were twins in her womb.
The first came forth ruddy, all over like a hairy mantle, and his name was called Esau.
Afterward his brother came forth, with his hand holding Esau's heel, and his name was called Jacob.

aspect.normalized: Isaac was sixty years old when Rebekah bore them.

actuality.normalized: The boys grew: Esau was a cunning hunter, a man of the field; Jacob was a quiet man, dwelling in tents.
Isaac loved Esau because he ate of his venison, and Rebekah loved Jacob.
Jacob cooked pottage, and Esau came in from the field faint.
Esau said to Jacob, 'Let me swallow some of this red pottage, for I am faint'; therefore his name was called Edom.
Jacob said, 'Sell me first thy birthright.' Esau said, 'Behold, I am at the point to die; and what profit shall the birthright do to me?'
Jacob said, 'Swear to me first'; Esau swore to him and sold his birthright unto Jacob.
Jacob gave Esau bread and lentil pottage; he ate and drank, rose up, and went his way; so Esau despised his birthright.
There was a famine in the land, beside the first famine in the days of Abraham; Isaac went to Abimelech king of the Philistines, unto Gerar.

The LORD appeared to Isaac and said, 'Go not down to Egypt; dwell in the land which I shall tell thee of; sojourn in this land and I will be with thee and bless thee; to thee and thy seed I will give all these lands and establish the oath I swore to Abraham; I will multiply thy seed as the stars and give thy seed these lands; by thy seed shall all nations of the earth bless themselves, because Abraham hearkened to My voice and kept My charge, commandments, statutes, and laws.' Isaac dwelt in Gerar.
The men of the place asked Isaac of his wife; he said, 'She is my sister,' for he feared to say 'my wife' lest the men of the place kill him for Rebekah because she was fair to look upon.
After he had been there a long time, Abimelech looked out at a window and saw Isaac sporting with Rebekah his wife.

Abimelech called Isaac and said, 'Surely she is thy wife; how saidst thou, She is my sister?' Isaac said, 'Because I said, Lest I die because of her.' Abimelech said, 'What is this thou hast done to us? One of the people might easily have lain with thy wife, and thou wouldest have brought guilt upon us.' Abimelech charged all the people, saying, 'He that toucheth this man or his wife shall surely be put to death.'

Isaac sowed in that land and found in the same year a hundredfold; the LORD blessed him and the man grew until he became very great, having possessions of flocks and herds and a great household; the Philistines envied him.
All the wells which his father's servants had digged in the days of Abraham his father, the Philistines stopped and filled with earth.
Abimelech said to Isaac, 'Go from us, for thou art much mightier than we'; Isaac departed and encamped in the valley of Gerar and dwelt there.

Isaac dug again the wells of water which had been dug in the days of Abraham his father (stopped by the Philistines after Abraham's death) and called their names after the names by which his father had called them.
Isaac's servants dug in the valley and found there a well of living water.
The herdmen of Gerar strove with Isaac's herdmen, saying 'The water is ours'; he called the name of the well Esek because they contended with him.
They dug another well and strove for that also; he called its name Sitnah.
He removed from there and dug another well, and for that they strove not; he called its name Rehoboth and said, 'For now the LORD hath made room for us, and we shall be fruitful in the land.'
Isaac went up from there to Beer-sheba.
The LORD appeared to him that night and said, 'I am the God of Abraham thy father; fear not, for I am with thee and will bless thee and multiply thy seed for My servant Abraham's sake.'
Isaac built an altar there, called upon the name of the LORD, pitched his tent there, and Isaac's servants dug a well.
Abimelech went to Isaac from Gerar, with Ahuzzath his friend and Phicol the captain of his host.
Isaac said to them, 'Why are ye come unto me, seeing ye hate me and have sent me away from you?'
They said, 'We saw plainly that the LORD was with thee.'

entity.description: A well named by Isaac; its naming is associated with the city's name Beer-sheba.
Wife of Esau; daughter of Beeri the Hittite.
A Hittite; father of Judith.
Wife of Esau; daughter of Elon the Hittite.
A Hittite; father of Basemath.
Servants belonging to Isaac.

actuality.normalized: Abimelech and his companions proposed an oath and a covenant with Isaac, asking that he do them no hurt, asserting they had done him only good and sent him away in peace, and declaring him the blessed of the LORD.
Isaac made them a feast, and they ate and drank.
They rose early, swore one to another, and Isaac sent them away; they departed from him in peace.
Isaac's servants came and told him concerning the well they had dug, saying, 'We have found water.' He called it Shibah; therefore the name of the city is Beer-sheba unto this day.

aspect.normalized: Esau was forty years old when he took wives.

actuality.normalized: Esau took to wife Judith the daughter of Beeri the Hittite and Basemath the daughter of Elon the Hittite.
Judith and Basemath were a bitterness of spirit to Isaac and to Rebekah.
When Isaac was old and his eyes were dim so that he could not see, he called Esau his elder son.
Isaac said he was old and did not know the day of his death; he asked Esau to take weapons, go to the field, hunt venison, and make savoury food that he might eat and bless him before he died.
Rebekah heard when Isaac spoke to Esau; Esau went to the field to hunt for venison and to bring it.
Rebekah told Jacob that Isaac had told Esau to bring venison, make savoury food, eat, and bless him before the LORD before his death; she commanded Jacob to hearken to her voice.
Rebekah instructed Jacob to fetch two good kids of the goats so she could make savoury food for Isaac, and that he should bring it to his father so that he might bless him before his death.
Jacob expressed concern that Esau is a hairy man and he a smooth man; his father might feel him and he would seem a mocker and bring a curse upon himself, not a blessing.
His mother said, 'Upon me be thy curse, my son; only hearken to my voice, and go fetch me them.'
Jacob went, fetched, and brought the kids to his mother; Rebekah made savoury food as his father loved.
Rebekah took Esau's choicest garments and put them upon Jacob her younger son; she put the skins of the kids of the goats upon his hands and the smooth of his neck.
She gave the savoury food and the bread she had prepared into Jacob's hand.

Jacob came to his father and said, 'I am Esau thy first-born; arise, sit and eat of my venison, that thy soul may bless me'; when Isaac asked how he found it so quickly, Jacob said, 'Because the LORD thy God sent me good speed.'

Isaac asked Jacob to come near that he might feel him, to know if he were Esau; Isaac felt him and said, 'The voice is Jacob's voice, but the hands are Esau's hands,' and discerned him not because his hands were hairy; so he blessed him.
Isaac ate and drank; then asked his son to come near and kiss him; he kissed him, and Isaac smelled the smell of his raiment and blessed him.

Isaac blessed Jacob: God give thee of the dew of heaven and the fat places of the earth, plenty of corn and wine; let peoples serve thee and nations bow down to thee; be lord over thy brethren and thy mother's sons bow down to thee; cursed be everyone that curseth thee, and blessed be everyone that blesseth thee.
As soon as Isaac finished blessing Jacob and Jacob had scarcely gone out from Isaac's presence, Esau came in from his hunting.
Esau also made savoury food, brought it to his father, and asked him to arise and eat of his son's venison that his soul might bless him.
Upon learning Esau's identity, Isaac trembled exceedingly and said he had eaten of the venison brought by another and had blessed him, and he shall be blessed.
When Esau heard his father's words, he cried with an exceeding great and bitter cry and asked his father to bless him also.
Isaac said, 'Thy brother came with guile and hath taken away thy blessing.'

Esau said, 'Is he not rightly named Jacob? for he hath supplanted me these two times: he took away my birthright, and now he hath taken away my blessing,' and asked if a blessing was reserved for him.
Isaac answered Esau that he had made Jacob lord over him, given him his brethren for servants, and sustained him with corn and wine; he asked what he could then do for Esau.
Esau begged for a blessing and wept.

Isaac spoke to Esau: 'Of the fat places of the earth shall be thy dwelling and of the dew of heaven from above; by thy sword shalt thou live and thou shalt serve thy brother; and it shall come to pass when thou shalt break loose, thou shalt shake his yoke from off thy neck.'
Esau hated Jacob because of the blessing with which his father blessed him and said in his heart that when the days of mourning for his father are at hand, then he will slay his brother Jacob.
The words of Esau were told to Rebekah; she sent and called Jacob her younger son and warned him that Esau comforts himself, purposing to kill him.

entity.description: Jacob’s maternal uncle; called 'the Aramean'.
Region/city to which Jacob fled and journeyed.
Local Hittite women of the land; prospective wives Rebekah opposes for Jacob.
Canaanite women whom Isaac forbids Jacob to marry.
Rebekah’s father; grandfather of Jacob and Esau.
Divine epithet invoked by Isaac in blessing Jacob.
Esau’s additional wife; daughter of Ishmael and sister of Nebaioth.
Peoples/region reached by Jacob after departing Bethel.
Place named by Jacob after his dream; formerly called Luz.
Former name of the city Jacob renamed Bethel.
The stone Jacob set up as a pillar at Bethel and anointed with oil.
A ladder set up on earth with its top reaching heaven, seen in Jacob’s dream.
Heavenly beings ascending and descending on the ladder in Jacob’s dream.
A well in the field with a great stone on its mouth, used by local shepherds.

entity.primary_reference: Great stone on the well’s mouth
entity.description: Large covering stone over the field well’s mouth.
Local men tending flocks who water them at the well in Haran’s vicinity.
Younger daughter of Laban; shepherdess; later Jacob’s intended.
Elder daughter of Laban; sister of Rachel.

actuality.normalized: Rebekah instructed Jacob to hearken to her, arise, and flee to Laban in Haran, to tarry a few days until Esau’s fury and anger turn away; she would send and fetch him, lest she be bereaved of both sons in one day.
Rebekah told Isaac she was weary of life because of the daughters of Heth and feared Jacob taking a wife of such daughters of the land.
Isaac called, blessed, and charged Jacob not to take a wife of the daughters of Canaan but to go to Paddan-aram to Bethuel’s house and take a wife from the daughters of Laban.

Isaac invoked God Almighty to bless Jacob, make him fruitful and multiply into a congregation of peoples, give him the blessing of Abraham to him and his seed, that he inherit the land of his sojournings given to Abraham.
Isaac sent Jacob away, and Jacob went to Paddan-aram unto Laban son of Bethuel the Aramean, Rebekah’s brother.

Esau observed that Isaac had blessed Jacob, sent him to Paddan-aram with the charge not to take Canaanite wives, and that Jacob obeyed and went; seeing the daughters of Canaan displeased Isaac, Esau went to Ishmael and took Mahalath, sister of Nebaioth, as an additional wife.
Jacob departed from Beer-sheba toward Haran, came upon a place at sundown, took a stone for his head, and lay down to sleep.
Jacob dreamed of a ladder set up on the earth with its top reaching to heaven and the angels of God ascending and descending on it.

The LORD stood beside Jacob and declared: the land where he lies will be given to him and his seed; his seed will be as the dust of the earth and spread west, east, north, south; in him and his seed all families of the earth will be blessed; the LORD will be with him, keep him, and bring him back to this land, not leaving him until fulfilling the word spoken.
Jacob awoke and said the LORD is in this place and he knew it not; he feared and declared the place to be the house of God and the gate of heaven.
Jacob rose early, took the stone from under his head, set it up as a pillar, and poured oil upon its top.
He called the place Bethel; the city’s name was Luz at the first.

Jacob vowed that if God would be with him, keep him in his way, provide bread and raiment, and bring him back in peace to his father’s house, then the LORD would be his God; the pillar would be God’s house and of all given to him he would surely give the tenth.
Jacob went on his journey and came to the land of the children of the east.
Jacob saw a well in the field with three flocks lying by it; a great stone was on the well’s mouth; when all flocks were gathered, they rolled the stone, watered the sheep, and replaced the stone.

participants.subject_reference: Great stone on the well’s mouth

actuality.normalized: Jacob questioned the shepherds, who said they were of Haran; they knew Laban son of Nahor and said it was well with him, and that Rachel his daughter was coming with the sheep.
Jacob urged them to water the sheep and feed them, but they replied they could not until all flocks were gathered and the stone rolled from the well’s mouth.
While he was speaking, Rachel came with her father’s sheep, for she tended them.
Seeing Rachel and Laban’s flock, Jacob rolled the stone from the well’s mouth and watered the flock.

participants.subject_reference: Great stone on the well’s mouth

actuality.normalized: Jacob kissed Rachel, lifted up his voice, and wept.
Jacob told Rachel he was her father’s kinsman and Rebekah’s son; she ran and told her father.
Hearing the tidings of Jacob, Laban ran to meet him, embraced and kissed him, and brought him to his house; Jacob told Laban all these things.
Laban said to Jacob, 'Surely thou art my bone and my flesh,' and Jacob abode with him a month.
Laban asked Jacob to name his wages, noting that though a relative he should not serve for nothing; Laban had two daughters, Leah the elder and Rachel the younger.
Leah’s eyes were weak, but Rachel was of beautiful form and fair to look upon.
Jacob loved Rachel and offered to serve seven years for her; Laban agreed that it was better to give her to Jacob than to another man and asked him to abide.
Jacob served seven years for Rachel, and they seemed to him but a few days for the love he had to her.
Jacob said to Laban, 'Give me my wife, for my days are fulfilled, that I may go in unto her'; Laban gathered all the men of the place and made a feast.
In the evening Laban took Leah his daughter and brought her to Jacob.

entity.description: Leah’s handmaid, later given to Jacob as a wife/concubine.
Rachel’s handmaid, given to Jacob as a wife/concubine.
Jacob’s firstborn son by Leah.
Jacob’s second son by Leah.
Jacob’s third son by Leah.
Jacob’s fourth son by Leah.
Jacob’s son by Bilhah (Rachel’s handmaid).
Jacob’s son by Bilhah (Rachel’s handmaid).
Jacob’s son by Zilpah (Leah’s handmaid).
Jacob’s son by Zilpah (Leah’s handmaid).
Jacob’s son by Leah (her fifth son).
Jacob’s son by Leah (her sixth son).
Jacob’s daughter by Leah.
Jacob’s son by Rachel.
Plants found by Reuben during wheat harvest; object of exchange between Leah and Rachel.
Troughs where the flocks came to drink; location where peeled rods were set.
Rods Jacob peeled with white streaks to influence breeding.
Sons of Laban who received the separated animals.

actuality.normalized: Jacob went in unto Leah.
Laban gave Zilpah his handmaid unto his daughter Leah for a handmaid.
In the morning Jacob discovered it was Leah and said to Laban that he had served for Rachel and asked why he had been beguiled.
Laban replied that in their place the younger is not given before the firstborn.
Laban proposed Jacob fulfill Leah’s bridal week, then receive Rachel also for seven additional years of service.
Jacob did so, fulfilled her week, and Laban gave him Rachel his daughter to wife.
Laban gave to Rachel his daughter Bilhah his handmaid to be her handmaid.
Jacob went in also unto Rachel; he loved Rachel more than Leah and served Laban yet seven other years.
The LORD saw that Leah was hated and opened her womb, but Rachel was barren.
Leah conceived and bore a son, naming him Reuben, saying the LORD has looked upon her affliction and now her husband will love her.
Leah conceived again and bore a son, naming him Simeon, saying the LORD heard that she was hated and gave her this son also.
Leah conceived again and bore a son, naming him Levi, saying now her husband will be joined to her because she has borne him three sons.
Leah conceived again and bore a son, naming him Judah, saying she will praise the LORD; then she left off bearing.

Rachel, seeing she bore Jacob no children, envied her sister and demanded children of Jacob or else she would die; Jacob’s anger was kindled and he replied that he was not in God’s stead who withheld fruit of the womb.
Rachel gave Bilhah her maid to Jacob to wife so that she might be built up through her; Jacob went in unto Bilhah.
Bilhah conceived and bore Jacob a son; Rachel named him Dan, saying God has judged her, heard her voice, and given a son.
Bilhah conceived again and bore Jacob a second son; Rachel named him Naphtali, saying she wrestled with her sister and prevailed.
When Leah saw she had ceased bearing, she took Zilpah her handmaid and gave her to Jacob to wife.
Zilpah bore Jacob a son; Leah said, 'Fortune is come!' and named him Gad.
Zilpah bore Jacob a second son; Leah said she is happy and that daughters will call her happy, and named him Asher.

During wheat harvest Reuben found mandrakes and brought them to Leah; Rachel asked Leah for some; Leah protested about taking her husband and the mandrakes; Rachel agreed that Jacob would lie with Leah that night in exchange.
Jacob came from the field in the evening; Leah met him and said she had hired him with her son’s mandrakes; he lay with her that night.
God hearkened unto Leah; she conceived and bore Jacob a fifth son, and named him Issachar saying God has given her hire because she gave her handmaid to her husband.
Leah conceived again and bore Jacob a sixth son, naming him Zebulun and saying God has endowed her with a good dowry and now her husband will dwell with her.
Afterwards Leah bore a daughter and called her name Dinah.
God remembered Rachel, hearkened to her, and opened her womb; she conceived and bore a son and said God has taken away her reproach; she named him Joseph, saying the LORD add to her another son.
After Rachel had borne Joseph, Jacob asked Laban to send him away to his own place and country, requesting his wives and children for whom he had served.
Laban said he had found favor and observed by signs that the LORD blessed him for Jacob’s sake; he asked Jacob to appoint his wages.
Jacob stated that Laban had little before he came and it increased abundantly with the LORD’s blessing; he asked when he might provide for his own house.

When asked what to give, Jacob requested to pass through the flock, removing every speckled and spotted goat and every dark sheep; such would be his hire while he continued to feed and keep Laban’s flock.
Jacob stated his righteousness would witness later: any animal not matching the agreed markings found with him would be counted stolen.
Laban agreed according to Jacob’s word.
That day Laban removed the streaked and spotted he-goats, the speckled and spotted she-goats with white, and all the dark sheep, and gave them into the hand of his sons.
Laban set a three days’ journey between himself and Jacob, and Jacob fed the rest of Laban’s flocks.
Jacob took fresh rods of poplar, almond, and plane-tree and peeled white streaks in them, making the white appear.
He set the peeled rods before the flocks in the watering-troughs where the flocks came to drink, and they conceived when they came to drink.
The flocks conceived at the sight of the rods and brought forth streaked, speckled, and spotted young.
Jacob separated the lambs, set the faces of the flocks toward the streaked and all the dark in Laban’s flock, and put his own droves apart, not putting them with Laban’s flock.

entity.description: Household idols stolen by Rachel from her father Laban.
The river crossed by Jacob when fleeing Laban.
Mountainous region where Jacob was overtaken and where both camps pitched.
Relatives/kinsmen accompanying Laban in pursuit of Jacob.
Heavenly messenger who spoke to Jacob in a dream.
Divine self-identification recalling Jacob’s anointing of the pillar and vow at Bethel.
Divine epithet invoked by Jacob alongside the God of Abraham.
Saddle of the camel where Rachel hid the teraphim.
Stone pillar set up by Jacob as part of a covenant with Laban.

actuality.normalized: Whenever the stronger of the flock conceived, Jacob laid the rods before their eyes in the gutters so they might conceive among the rods; when the flock were feeble, he did not set the rods, so the feebler were Laban’s and the stronger Jacob’s.
The man increased exceedingly, having large flocks, maid-servants and men-servants, camels and asses.
Jacob heard Laban’s sons say he had taken away all that was their father’s and gotten all this wealth; Jacob saw Laban’s countenance was not toward him as before.
The LORD told Jacob to return to the land of his fathers and kindred, promising to be with him.

Jacob called Rachel and Leah to the field by his flock and told them their father’s countenance was not toward him as before, but the God of his father had been with him; they knew he had served their father with all his power.
Jacob said Laban mocked him and changed his wages ten times, but God did not suffer him to hurt Jacob.
Jacob recounted that whenever Laban said the speckled would be Jacob’s wages, all the flock bore speckled; and when he said the streaked would be Jacob’s wages, all the flock bore streaked.
Thus God took away the cattle of Laban and gave them to Jacob.
At the time the flock conceived, Jacob saw in a dream that the he-goats leaping on the flock were streaked, speckled, and grizzled.
The Angel of God spoke to Jacob in the dream, telling him to lift up his eyes and see the he-goats streaked, speckled, and grizzled, for God had seen all that Laban did to him.
God of Bethel identified Himself, recalling Jacob’s anointing of the pillar and his vow, and commanded Jacob to arise, leave this land, and return to the land of his nativity.

Rachel and Leah answered that they had no portion or inheritance in their father’s house, that he sold them and devoured their price; they said the riches God took from their father were theirs and their children’s, and told Jacob to do whatever God had said.
Jacob rose, set his sons and wives on the camels, carried away all his cattle and substance gathered in Paddan-aram, and went to Isaac his father to the land of Canaan.
While Laban went to shear his sheep, Rachel stole her father’s teraphim.
Jacob outwitted Laban the Aramean by not telling him that he fled; he fled with all he had, crossed the River, and set his face toward the mountain of Gilead.
It was told Laban on the third day that Jacob fled; he took his brethren and pursued seven days’ journey and overtook him in the mountain of Gilead.
God came to Laban in a night dream and warned him to speak neither good nor bad to Jacob.
Laban came up with Jacob; Jacob had pitched his tent in the mountain, and Laban with his brethren pitched in the mountain of Gilead.

Laban accused Jacob of outwitting him and carrying away his daughters as captives of the sword; he asked why Jacob fled secretly and outwitted him, not telling him so he might send him away with mirth and songs, tabret and harp, and kiss his sons and daughters; he said Jacob had done foolishly.
Laban asserted power to do harm but said the God of Jacob’s father warned him the night before not to speak good or bad to Jacob.

Laban asked why Jacob stole his gods though he longed for his father’s house; Jacob replied he was afraid Laban would take his daughters by force and declared that whoever was found with the gods should not live, inviting judgment before their brethren; Jacob did not know Rachel had stolen them.
Laban searched Jacob’s tent, Leah’s tent, and the tents of the two maid-servants and found nothing; he then entered Rachel’s tent.
Rachel had taken the teraphim, placed them in the camel’s saddle, and sat on them; Laban felt about the tent but did not find them.
Rachel told her father not to be angry that she could not rise before him because the manner of women was upon her; he searched but did not find the teraphim.
Jacob was wroth and strove with Laban, demanding to know his trespass or sin; he challenged Laban to set what he had found before their brethren to judge between them.
Jacob recounted twenty years of service: ewes and she-goats did not miscarry, he did not eat the rams; losses from beasts he bore and Laban required it of his hand whether stolen by day or by night.
Jacob described hardship: by day drought consumed him and by night frost; his sleep fled from his eyes.
Jacob stated he served twenty years in Laban’s house—fourteen for the two daughters and six for the flock—and Laban changed his wages ten times.

Jacob affirmed that except for the God of his father, the God of Abraham, and the Fear of Isaac being on his side, Laban would have sent him away empty; God saw his affliction and the labor of his hands and gave judgment the previous night.
Laban answered that the daughters, children, and flocks were his, and all Jacob saw was his; he asked what he could do for his daughters or their children.
Laban proposed they make a covenant to be a witness between them; Jacob took a stone and set it up for a pillar.

entity.description: Stone heap raised by Jacob and kinsmen as covenant witness; also called Mizpah.
Pillar referenced by Laban as boundary/witness with Jacob.
Divine epithet invoked by Laban in oath formula with the God of Abraham and their father.
Place named by Jacob after meeting the angels of God; ‘God’s camp’.
Heavenly beings who met Jacob on the way.
Land where Esau was dwelling; the field of Edom.
Region associated with Esau; also called the field of Edom.
Group accompanying Esau to meet Jacob.
River Jacob crossed previously with only his staff.
Stream/ford crossed by Jacob with family and goods.
Place named by Jacob after wrestling; ‘I have seen God face to face’.
Anatomical tendon not eaten by the children of Israel, commemorating Jacob’s thigh being touched.
Collective descendants of Israel (Jacob), referenced regarding dietary custom.
Patriarch renamed ‘Israel’ after wrestling with a man/angel at night.

actuality.normalized: Jacob told his brethren to gather stones; they took stones, made a heap, and ate there by the heap.
Laban called the heap Jegar-sahadutha, but Jacob called it Galeed.
Laban said the heap is witness between him and Jacob that day; therefore its name was called Galeed and Mizpah, invoking the LORD to watch between them when absent.
Laban set covenant conditions: Jacob must not afflict his daughters nor take wives beside them; God is witness between them.
Laban pointed to the heap and pillar as witnesses, stipulating neither party would pass them for harm.
Laban invoked the God of Abraham, the God of Nahor, and the God of their father to judge between them; Jacob swore by the Fear of his father Isaac.
Jacob offered a sacrifice in the mountain, called his brethren to eat bread; they ate and lodged there all night.
Early in the morning Laban rose, kissed his sons and daughters, blessed them, departed, and returned to his place.
Jacob went on his way and the angels of God met him; he said, ‘This is God’s camp,’ and named the place Mahanaim.
Jacob sent messengers ahead to Esau his brother to the land of Seir, field of Edom, commanding the message of his sojourn with Laban and his intent to find favor.
Messengers returned saying Esau was coming to meet Jacob with four hundred men; Jacob was greatly afraid and distressed and divided people and herds into two camps with a contingency plan.

Jacob prayed to the God of Abraham and Isaac, citing the command to return and the promise to do him good; he confessed unworthiness, recalled crossing the Jordan with his staff and now being two camps, and asked deliverance from Esau while recalling the promise of innumerable seed.
Jacob lodged that night and selected a present for Esau: 200 she-goats, 20 he-goats, 200 ewes, 20 rams, 30 milch camels with colts, 40 kine and 10 bulls, 20 she-asses and 10 foals.

He delivered the droves into his servants’ hands, each by itself, and ordered them to pass before him with space between droves; he scripted their answers to Esau, saying the animals are Jacob’s present for ‘my lord Esau’ and that Jacob is behind.

He commanded the second, the third, and all following droves similarly, saying he would appease Esau with the present before seeing his face, hoping for acceptance; the present passed before him while he lodged that night in the camp.
By night Jacob took his two wives, two handmaids, and eleven children and passed over the ford of the Jabbok; he sent them and all he had over the stream.
Jacob was left alone, and a man wrestled with him until daybreak; when the man saw he did not prevail, he touched the hollow of Jacob’s thigh, straining it as they wrestled.
The man asked to be let go at daybreak; Jacob refused unless blessed.
The man asked Jacob’s name and said it would no more be Jacob but Israel, because he had striven with God and with men and prevailed.
Jacob asked the man’s name; he declined and blessed Jacob there.
Jacob named the place Peniel, saying he had seen God face to face and his life was preserved; the sun rose as he passed over Peniel, and he limped upon his thigh.
Therefore the children of Israel do not eat the sinew of the thigh-vein upon the hollow of the thigh to this day, because the hollow of Jacob’s thigh was touched in the sinew.
Jacob lifted his eyes and saw Esau coming with four hundred men; he arranged the families: handmaids with children foremost, Leah and her children after, and Rachel with Joseph hindmost.
Jacob passed before them and bowed to the ground seven times until he drew near to his brother.
Esau ran to meet Jacob, embraced him, fell on his neck, kissed him, and they wept.

Esau asked about the women and children; Jacob replied they are the children whom God graciously gave his servant; the handmaids and their children, then Leah and her children, and then Joseph and Rachel came near and bowed.
Esau asked about the camp he met; Jacob said it was to find favor in his lord’s sight; Esau said, ‘I have enough.’

entity.description: Place where Jacob built a house and made booths for his cattle; named for the booths.
City in the land of Canaan where Jacob encamped and purchased a parcel of ground.
Father of Shechem, leader associated with the city of Shechem.
Collective sellers of the parcel of ground to Jacob.
Monetary units used by Jacob to purchase the parcel of ground (a hundred pieces).
Altar erected by Jacob and named ‘El-elohe-Israel’.
Daughter of Leah and Jacob; central figure in the Shechem incident.
Son of Hamor the Hivite, prince of the land.
People group associated with Hamor and Shechem.
Gate where Hamor and Shechem addressed the men of their city.
Son of Jacob and Leah; Dinah’s brother and participant in the third-day assault.
Son of Jacob and Leah; Dinah’s brother and participant in the third-day assault.
Inhabitants of the land whom Jacob feared would unite against him.
Place in the land of Canaan where God appeared to Jacob; also called Luz.
Idols and foreign gods held by Jacob’s household, later buried.
Rings that were in the ears of Jacob’s household, surrendered and hidden.
Tree under which Jacob hid the foreign gods and ear rings near Shechem.
Fear from God that fell upon surrounding cities, preventing pursuit of Jacob’s sons.
alias_list: fear of God on the cities

actuality.normalized: Esau told Jacob to keep what he had; Jacob insisted and urged Esau to receive the present, likening seeing Esau’s face to seeing the face of God; Esau took it.

Esau proposed they journey together with him going before; Jacob declined, citing tender children and sucking herds, and asked his lord to pass on while he would come gently to Seir; Esau offered to leave some folk, but Jacob declined; Esau returned that day to Seir.
Jacob journeyed to Succoth, built a house, made booths for his cattle, and named the place Succoth.

Jacob came in peace to the city of Shechem in Canaan from Paddan-aram, encamped before the city, bought the parcel of ground from the children of Hamor for a hundred pieces of money, erected an altar and called it El-elohe-Israel.
Dinah went out to see the daughters of the land; Shechem the son of Hamor saw her, took her, lay with her, and humbled her.
Shechem’s soul clung to Dinah; he loved the damsel and spoke comfortingly to her, then asked his father Hamor to get her as wife.
Jacob heard that Dinah was defiled while his sons were in the field with the cattle, and he kept silent until they came.
Hamor went out to Jacob to speak with him; Jacob’s sons, hearing, came from the field, were grieved and very wroth because of the vile deed in Israel.
Hamor proposed intermarriage, dwelling, trading, and possessions; Shechem offered to pay any dowry and gift to have Dinah as wife.
The sons of Jacob answered Shechem and Hamor with guile because Dinah was defiled, setting the condition that every male be circumcised, else they would take their daughter and depart.
Their words pleased Hamor and Shechem; the young man did not delay to do the thing because he delighted in Jacob’s daughter and was honored above his father’s house.

Hamor and Shechem addressed the men at the city gate to consent to circumcision so the groups might become one people, arguing the land was large and their cattle and substance would become theirs; all males at the gate were circumcised.

On the third day, while they were in pain, Simeon and Levi took swords, came upon the city unawares, slew all the males, killed Hamor and Shechem with the sword’s edge, and took Dinah out of Shechem’s house.

The sons of Jacob came upon the slain, spoiled the city, taking flocks, herds, asses, and what was in the city and field; they took all wealth, little ones, and wives captive, spoiling all in the houses.

Jacob rebuked Simeon and Levi for making him odious to the land’s inhabitants—the Canaanites and Perizzites—fearing they would gather to smite and destroy him and his house; they replied, ‘Should one deal with our sister as with a harlot?’
God told Jacob to arise, go up to Beth-el, dwell there, and make an altar to God who appeared when he fled from Esau.

Jacob commanded his household and all with him to put away strange gods, purify themselves, and change garments; he resolved to go up to Beth-el and make an altar to God who answered him in distress and was with him in the way.
They gave Jacob all the foreign gods in their hand and the ear rings in their ears; Jacob hid them under the terebinth by Shechem.
They journeyed and the terror of God was upon surrounding cities so they did not pursue the sons of Jacob.
Jacob came to Luz (Beth-el) in the land of Canaan, he and all the people with him.

entity.description: Name Jacob gave to the place at Beth-el where God was revealed to him when he fled from Esau.
Rebekah’s nurse who died and was buried below Beth-el under the oak.
The oak below Beth-el where Deborah was buried; its name means ‘oak of weeping’.
Monument Jacob set up upon Rachel’s grave, standing ‘unto this day’.
Location on the way from Beth-el where Rachel died and was buried; identified as Beth-lehem.
Youngest son of Jacob and Rachel; named ‘Ben-oni’ by his mother as she died, but his father called him ‘Benjamin’.
Place beyond which Israel spread his tent after Rachel’s burial.
Hebron, also called Kiriath-arba; where Abraham and Isaac sojourned and where Jacob came to Isaac.
Son of Isaac; also called Edom.
The mountainous region where Esau dwelt; associated with Edom.
One of Esau’s wives; daughter of Elon the Hittite.
One of Esau’s wives; daughter of Anah, daughter of Zibeon the Hivite.
One of Esau’s wives; Ishmael’s daughter, sister of Nebaioth.
Son of Esau by Adah.
Son of Esau by Basemath.
Son of Esau by Oholibamah.
Son of Esau by Oholibamah.
Son of Esau by Oholibamah; later also listed among chiefs.
Concubine to Eliphaz, Esau’s son; also named as Lotan’s sister.
Son born to Eliphaz by Timna.
Eponymous ancestor of the Horites; his descendants inhabited the land of Edom.
People associated with Seir; inhabitants of the land in Edom.
Descendant of Seir; noted for finding the hot springs in the wilderness while feeding Zibeon’s asses.
Geothermal springs discovered by Anah while tending the asses of Zibeon.

actuality.normalized: Jacob built an altar there and called the place El-beth-el because God had been revealed to him when he fled from his brother.
Deborah, Rebekah’s nurse, died and was buried below Beth-el under the oak named Allon-bacuth.
God appeared again to Jacob coming from Paddan-aram, blessed him, and affirmed his name as Israel.
God Almighty charged Jacob to be fruitful and multiply; nations and kings would come from him, and the land given to Abraham and Isaac would be given to him and to his seed.
God went up from Jacob in the place where He spoke with him.
Jacob set up a stone pillar at the place of God’s speech, poured a drink-offering on it, and poured oil on it.
Jacob called the name of the place where God spoke with him ‘Beth-el’.
As they journeyed from Beth-el and were still some way from Ephrath, Rachel went into hard labour; the midwife told her not to fear, for she had a son.
As Rachel’s soul was departing, she named the child ‘Ben-oni’, but his father called him ‘Benjamin’.
Rachel died and was buried on the way to Ephrath (Beth-lehem).
Jacob set up a pillar upon Rachel’s grave; it stands as the pillar of Rachel’s grave unto this day.
Israel journeyed and pitched his tent beyond Migdal-eder.
While Israel dwelt in the land, Reuben went and lay with Bilhah, his father’s concubine; Israel heard of it.

The twelve sons of Jacob were enumerated: sons of Leah—Reuben (first-born), Simeon, Levi, Judah, Issachar, Zebulun; sons of Rachel—Joseph and Benjamin; sons of Bilhah—Dan and Naphtali; sons of Zilpah—Gad and Asher; these were born in Paddan-aram.
Jacob came to Isaac his father at Mamre (Kiriath-arba/Hebron), where Abraham and Isaac sojourned.
Isaac lived 180 years, expired and died, and was gathered to his people; Esau and Jacob his sons buried him.
Esau took his wives from the daughters of Canaan—Adah, Oholibamah, and Basemath—and they bore him Eliphaz, Reuel, Jeush, Jalam, and Korah in the land of Canaan.
Esau took his household and possessions and went to a land away from his brother Jacob because their substance was too great to dwell together; he dwelt in the mountain-land of Seir.
Timna was concubine to Eliphaz, Esau’s son, and she bore Amalek to Eliphaz.
Chiefs descended from Esau were enumerated from the lines of Eliphaz, Reuel, and Oholibamah in the land of Edom.
The sons of Seir the Horite—Lotan, Shobal, Zibeon, Anah, Dishon, Ezer, and Dishan—and the Horite chiefs in the land of Edom were enumerated.
Lotan’s children were Hori and Hemam, and Lotan’s sister was Timna.
The children of Shobal were named: Alvan, Manahath, Ebal, Shepho, and Onam.
The children of Zibeon were Aiah and Anah; this Anah found the hot springs in the wilderness while feeding the asses of Zibeon his father.
The children of Anah were Dishon and Oholibamah (daughter of Anah).
The children of Dishon were Hemdan, Eshban, Ithran, and Cheran.
The children of Ezer were Bilhan, Zaavan, and Akan.

entity.description: One of the sons of Dishan the Horite.
One of the sons of Dishan the Horite.

actuality.normalized: The children of Dishan were Uz and Aran.
The chiefs of the Horites were listed: Lotan, Shobal, Zibeon, Anah, Dishon, Ezer, and Dishan, according to their chiefs in the land of Seir.
Kings reigned in the land of Edom before any king reigned over the children of Israel.

entity.description: An early king who reigned in Edom; his city was Dinhabah.
City associated with Bela son of Beor.

actuality.normalized: Bela son of Beor reigned in Edom; his city was Dinhabah.

entity.description: Succeeded Bela as king; from Bozrah.
City associated with Zerah, father of Jobab.

actuality.normalized: After Bela died, Jobab son of Zerah of Bozrah reigned in his stead.

entity.description: A king of Edom from the land of the Temanites.
Region associated with Husham’s origin.

actuality.normalized: After Jobab died, Husham of the land of the Temanites reigned in his stead.

entity.description: King of Edom who smote Midian in the field of Moab; his city was Avith.
People smitten by Hadad son of Bedad in the field of Moab.
Location where Hadad son of Bedad smote Midian.
City associated with Hadad son of Bedad.

actuality.normalized: After Husham died, Hadad son of Bedad reigned; he smote Midian in the field of Moab, and his city was Avith.

entity.description: King of Edom from Masrekah.
City associated with Samlah.

actuality.normalized: After Hadad died, Samlah of Masrekah reigned in his stead.

entity.description: King of Edom from Rehoboth by the River.
City associated with King Shaul.

actuality.normalized: After Samlah died, Shaul of Rehoboth by the River reigned in his stead.

entity.description: King of Edom who succeeded Shaul.

actuality.normalized: After Shaul died, Baal-hanan son of Achbor reigned in his stead.

entity.description: King who reigned after Baal-hanan; his city was Pau.
City associated with King Hadar.
Wife of King Hadar; daughter of Matred, daughter of Me-zahab.
Mother of Mehetabel; daughter of Me-zahab.
Grandparent of Mehetabel.

actuality.normalized: After Baal-hanan died, Hadar reigned; his city was Pau, and his wife's name was Mehetabel, daughter of Matred, daughter of Me-zahab.

The chiefs of Esau were listed by families and places: Timna, Alvah, Jetheth; Oholibamah, Elah, Pinon; Kenaz, Teman, Mibzar; Magdiel, Iram—according to their habitations in the land of their possession. This is Esau, father of the Edomites.

entity.description: Seventeenth-year-old son of Israel (Jacob), later sold into Egypt.
Special garment Israel made for Joseph.
Valley from which Israel sent Joseph to his brothers.
City where Joseph sought his brothers.
Place where Joseph found his brothers.
Region from which the Ishmaelite caravan came.
Merchant caravan that purchased Joseph and brought him to Egypt.
Merchantmen who passed by and drew Joseph from the pit.
Empty cistern into which Joseph was cast.

actuality.normalized: Jacob dwelt in the land of his father’s sojournings, in the land of Canaan.
Joseph, seventeen years old, shepherded with the sons of Bilhah and Zilpah and brought their evil report to their father.
Israel loved Joseph more than all his children and made him a coat of many colours; his brothers hated him and could not speak peaceably to him.
Joseph dreamed that his sheaf arose upright and his brothers’ sheaves bowed down to it; his brothers hated him yet more for his dreams and words.
Joseph dreamed again: the sun, the moon, and eleven stars bowed down to him; he told his father and brothers, his father rebuked him, his brothers envied him, but his father kept the saying in mind.
Israel sent Joseph from the vale of Hebron to check on his brothers and the flock at Shechem.
A man found Joseph wandering in the field and directed him to Dothan, where he found his brothers.
Seeing Joseph from afar, his brothers conspired to kill him, planning to say an evil beast devoured him to see what would become of his dreams.
Reuben intervened, urging them not to take his life but to cast him into a wilderness pit so he might later restore him to his father.
Joseph was stripped of his coat of many colours and cast into an empty pit without water; his brothers sat down to eat.
A caravan of Ishmaelites from Gilead, with camels bearing spicery, balm, and ladanum, was going to Egypt.
Judah proposed selling Joseph to the Ishmaelites rather than killing him; his brothers agreed.
Midianite merchantmen passed by; they drew Joseph up from the pit and sold him to the Ishmaelites for twenty shekels of silver, who brought Joseph into Egypt.
Reuben returned to the pit, found Joseph gone, rent his clothes, and lamented.
Joseph's brothers killed a he-goat, dipped Joseph’s coat in the blood, and sent the coat to their father saying, ‘This have we found.’
Jacob recognized Joseph’s coat and concluded an evil beast had devoured him; he believed Joseph was torn in pieces.
Jacob rent his garments, put sackcloth on his loins, and mourned for his son many days; all his sons and daughters tried to comfort him, but he refused, saying he would go down to the grave mourning.

entity.description: Egyptian officer of Pharaoh, captain of the guard.
Title of the ruler of Egypt.
Country where Joseph was taken and sold.

actuality.normalized: The Midianites sold Joseph in Egypt to Potiphar, an officer of Pharaoh and captain of the guard.

entity.description: Son of Jacob who left his brothers and later fathered Perez and Zerah by Tamar.
Judah’s friend from Adullam.

actuality.normalized: Judah went down from his brothers and stayed with his friend Hirah the Adullamite.

entity.description: A Canaanite man; father of Judah’s unnamed wife.
Unnamed Canaanite woman whom Judah married; mother of Er, Onan, and Shelah.

actuality.normalized: Judah married the daughter of Shua; she conceived and bore Er, then Onan, then Shelah at Chezib.

entity.description: First-born son of Judah and Shua’s daughter.
Second son of Judah and Shua’s daughter.
Third son of Judah and Shua’s daughter; born at Chezib.
Place where Shelah was born.
Daughter-in-law of Judah; later mother of Perez and Zerah by Judah.

actuality.normalized: Judah arranged for Tamar to marry Er, his first-born.
