Er was wicked in the LORD’s sight, and the LORD slew him.

Judah told Onan to perform a brother-in-law’s duty to raise up seed for his brother; Onan spilled the seed on the ground to avoid giving seed to his brother, which was evil in the LORD’s sight, and He slew him also.
Judah told Tamar to remain a widow at her father’s house until Shelah grew up, fearing he also might die; Tamar dwelt at her father’s house.

entity.description: Place to which Judah went for sheep-shearing.

actuality.normalized: After Judah’s wife (Shua’s daughter) died and he was comforted, he went with his friend Hirah to his sheep-shearers at Timnah.

entity.primary_reference: Enaim (entrance by the way to Timnah)
entity.description: Place where Tamar sat veiled.
Personal seal used as Tamar’s pledge.
Cord (possibly with the signet) used as a pledge.
Staff in Judah’s hand given as a pledge.

actuality.normalized: Hearing Judah was going to Timnah, Tamar removed her widow’s garments, veiled herself, and sat at the entrance of Enaim, for Shelah had grown and she had not been given to him.

participants.subject_reference: Enaim (entrance by the way to Timnah)

actuality.normalized: Judah, thinking Tamar a harlot because her face was covered, propositioned her; they agreed on a kid from the flock with a pledge: Judah’s signet, cord, and staff. He gave them and went in to her, and she conceived by him.

Judah sent a kid by Hirah to retrieve the pledge, but she was not found; the men said there had been no harlot there. Judah decided to let her keep the items to avoid shame, noting he had sent the kid.
About three months later Judah was told Tamar was pregnant by harlotry; he ordered her to be brought out and burned.

As she was brought out, Tamar sent to Judah: ‘By the man to whom these belong I am with child,’ asking him to discern the signet, cords, and staff. Judah acknowledged them and declared, ‘She is more righteous than I,’ since he had not given her to Shelah, and he did not know her again.

entity.description: Son of Judah and Tamar, twin who breached first.
Son of Judah and Tamar, twin marked with a scarlet thread.

actuality.normalized: In Tamar’s travail, one twin put out a hand and a scarlet thread was tied, but the other came out first and was named Perez; afterward the one with the scarlet thread came out and was named Zerah.
Potiphar bought Joseph from the Ishmaelites who had brought him down; Joseph was in his Egyptian master’s house.
The LORD was with Joseph and made him prosperous; his master saw this and Joseph found favour and served him.
Potiphar appointed Joseph overseer over his house and placed all he had into Joseph’s hand; from that time the LORD blessed the Egyptian’s house for Joseph’s sake, in the house and in the field.
Potiphar left all he had in Joseph’s hand and concerned himself only with the bread he ate; Joseph was handsome and well-favoured.

entity.description: Wife of Potiphar who sought to lie with Joseph.

actuality.normalized: After these things, Potiphar’s wife cast her eyes upon Joseph and said, ‘Lie with me.’
Joseph refused, explaining that his master had entrusted everything to him and withheld nothing but his wife because she is his wife.
Joseph refused to commit wickedness or sin against God by lying with his master’s wife, resisting her day after day and avoiding being with her.

entity.description: Garment seized by Potiphar’s wife during the attempted seduction; later used as alleged evidence.

actuality.normalized: Potiphar’s wife grabbed Joseph by his garment and demanded he lie with her; he left the garment in her hand and fled outside.
Seeing she had Joseph’s garment, Potiphar’s wife summoned the household men and falsely accused Joseph of attempting to lie with her, claiming she cried out.
She kept Joseph’s garment until her husband returned and repeated the accusation to him, calling Joseph a Hebrew servant who came to mock her.
Potiphar’s anger was kindled upon hearing his wife’s words.

entity.description: Detention place where the king’s prisoners were confined; Joseph was bound there.
Warden overseeing the prison where Joseph was confined.

actuality.normalized: Potiphar took Joseph and placed him in the prison where the king’s prisoners were bound.
The LORD was with Joseph, showed him kindness, and granted him favor with the prison keeper.
The warden put all the prisoners under Joseph’s hand; whatever was done there, Joseph was the doer, and the LORD made it prosper.

entity.description: Pharaoh’s officer in charge of the cup; later restored.
Pharaoh’s officer in charge of baking; later hanged.

actuality.normalized: Pharaoh became angry with his chief butler and chief baker and put them in custody in the captain of the guard’s house, in the prison where Joseph was confined.

entity.description: Official whose house contained the ward where Joseph served the butler and baker.

actuality.normalized: The captain of the guard assigned Joseph to attend the butler and baker; he ministered to them for a time.
Both the butler and the baker dreamed dreams in one night, each with its own interpretation, and were sad.
Joseph asked Pharaoh’s officers why they were sad; they said there was no interpreter. Joseph affirmed that interpretations belong to God and asked them to tell him the dreams.
The chief butler’s dream of a vine with three budding branches whose grapes he pressed into Pharaoh’s cup was recounted to Joseph.
Joseph interpreted the butler’s dream: the three branches represented three days; within three days Pharaoh would lift up his head and restore him to office.

Joseph asked the butler to remember him and show kindness by mentioning him to Pharaoh so he might be brought out, explaining he was stolen from the land of the Hebrews and had done nothing to deserve the dungeon.
The chief baker, encouraged by the favorable interpretation, described his dream of three baskets of white bread on his head, with birds eating from the top basket.
Joseph interpreted the baker’s dream: the three baskets were three days; within three days Pharaoh would lift up his head from off him and hang him, and birds would eat his flesh.

entity.description: Occasion on the third day when Pharaoh made a feast for all his servants and judged the fates of the butler and baker.

actuality.normalized: On the third day, Pharaoh held a birthday feast, restored the chief butler to his office, and hanged the chief baker—just as Joseph had interpreted.
Despite Joseph’s request, the chief butler did not remember him and forgot.

entity.description: River by which Pharaoh stood in his first dream.

actuality.normalized: After two full years, Pharaoh dreamed he stood by the river: seven fat, well-favored cows came up and fed in the reed-grass; seven lean, ill-favored cows came up and ate the fat cows.
Pharaoh dreamed a second time: seven full, good ears grew on one stalk, then seven thin ears blasted by the east wind sprang up and swallowed the full ears.

entity.primary_reference: Magicians and wise men of Egypt
entity.description: Pharaoh’s practitioners and sages called to interpret his dreams but unable to do so.

actuality.normalized: In the morning Pharaoh’s spirit was troubled; he summoned all the magicians and wise men of Egypt and told them his dreams, but none could interpret them.

participants.subject_reference: Magicians and wise men of Egypt

actuality.normalized: The chief butler confessed his fault to Pharaoh and recalled how he and the chief baker were imprisoned and how a young Hebrew, servant to the captain of the guard, interpreted their dreams.
Joseph interpreted each man’s dream correctly: the butler was restored to office and the baker was hanged.
Pharaoh urgently summoned Joseph from the dungeon; Joseph shaved, changed garments, and came before Pharaoh.
Pharaoh reported his un-interpretable dreams to Joseph; Joseph replied that interpretation belongs to God and God would give Pharaoh a favorable answer.
Pharaoh retold both dreams: seven fat cows devoured by seven lean cows by the river, and seven good ears swallowed by seven thin, east-wind–blasted ears.
Joseph declared the two dreams are one message: seven years of great plenty followed by seven years of very grievous famine in Egypt and beyond.
Joseph explained the doubling of the dream means the decree is established by God and will happen soon.
Joseph advised Pharaoh to appoint a discreet and wise man with overseers to collect a fifth of produce during the seven plentiful years, storing food in cities against the famine.
Joseph’s proposal pleased Pharaoh and all his servants.
Recognizing God’s spirit in Joseph, Pharaoh declared Joseph the most discreet and wise and set him over his house and all Egypt, second only to the throne.

entity.description: Seal of royal authority transferred to Joseph as part of his promotion.

actuality.normalized: Pharaoh invested Joseph with authority: giving him the signet ring, fine linen garments, and a gold chain.

entity.description: Ceremonial chariot used to parade Joseph as second-in-command.
Proclamation cried before Joseph during his procession.

actuality.normalized: Joseph rode in Pharaoh’s second chariot; heralds cried ‘Abrech’; Pharaoh set him over all the land and decreed no one could act without Joseph.

entity.description: Egyptian name given to Joseph upon elevation.
Daughter of Poti-phera, priest of On; given to Joseph as wife.
Egyptian priest; father of Asenath.
Egyptian city of the sun where Poti-phera served as priest.

actuality.normalized: Joseph, age thirty, began his administration and toured all Egypt.
During seven years of plenty the land yielded abundantly; Joseph gathered and stored city by city until the grain was beyond numbering, like sand of the sea.

entity.description: City granaries where Joseph laid up grain during the years of plenty.

actuality.normalized: Before the famine, Asenath bore Joseph two sons: Manasseh and Ephraim; Joseph named them acknowledging God made him forget his toil and made him fruitful.

entity.description: Joseph’s firstborn; name explained as ‘God has made me forget my toil and my father’s house.’
Joseph’s second son; name explained as ‘God has made me fruitful in the land of my affliction.’

actuality.normalized: The seven years of plenty ended and seven years of famine began just as Joseph said; famine spread to all lands, yet there was bread in Egypt.
As Egypt famished, people cried to Pharaoh for bread; Pharaoh directed them to Joseph to do whatever he said.
Joseph opened all the storehouses, selling grain to the Egyptians as the famine grew severe, and people from all countries came to buy.
Hearing there was grain in Egypt, Jacob sent his sons to buy so they might live and not die.
Joseph’s ten brothers went down to Egypt to buy grain.
Jacob refused to send Benjamin with his brothers, fearing harm might befall him.
The sons of Israel came among others to buy grain because the famine was in Canaan.
Joseph, governor of the land, sold grain to all; his brothers bowed down to him with their faces to the ground.
Joseph recognized his brothers, concealed his identity, spoke harshly, and interrogated them about their origin; they answered they had come from Canaan to buy food.
Remembering his dreams, Joseph accused them of being spies; they denied it, claiming to be upright men and sons of one man.
Joseph repeated the charge; they explained they were twelve brothers, the youngest with their father and one missing.
Joseph set a test: they would not leave unless their youngest brother came; he ordered one to go fetch him while the rest were bound.
He imprisoned them together for three days.
On the third day Joseph modified the terms out of fear of God: one brother would remain bound while the rest carried grain home and brought the youngest back to verify their words and live.
The brothers confessed guilt regarding Joseph’s earlier anguish, believing their present distress to be retribution.
Reuben reminded them he had warned against sinning against the child and said his blood was now required.
They did not realize Joseph understood them because an interpreter stood between them.
Joseph turned away and wept, then returned and bound Simeon before their eyes.
Joseph ordered their sacks filled with grain, each man’s money secretly returned, and provisions given for the journey; it was done.
They loaded their donkeys with grain and departed.
At a lodging place one brother found his money in his sack; all were terrified and wondered what God had done to them.
They reported to Jacob in Canaan the harsh treatment, the accusation of spying, and the requirement to bring the youngest brother to prove their honesty.
When they emptied their sacks, each man’s bundle of money was found; they and their father were afraid.
Jacob lamented that Joseph was gone, Simeon was detained, and they now sought to take Benjamin—declaring all these things had come against him.
Reuben offered his two sons as surety if he failed to return Benjamin, but Jacob refused, insisting Benjamin would not go lest sorrow bring his gray hairs to the grave.
The famine grew severe; after they had eaten the grain from Egypt, Jacob told them to go again and buy a little food.
Judah insisted they could not see the man’s face unless Benjamin was with them and refused to go without him.
Israel reproached them for revealing they had another brother; they explained the man had pressed them closely about their family, and they could not foresee the demand to bring the brother down.
Judah offered himself as surety for Benjamin, pledging lifelong blame if he failed, and urged immediate departure so all might live and not die.

Israel consented and instructed them to take a gift of the land’s choice produce, double money including the returned silver, and to take Benjamin; he prayed God Almighty to grant mercy and release Simeon and Benjamin.

entity.description: Youngest son of Jacob and Rachel; full brother of Joseph, kept back and later sent as surety condition.
One of Jacob’s sons, detained by Joseph as a guarantee until the brothers return with Benjamin.
A present for the Egyptian lord: balm, honey, spices, ladanum, nuts, and almonds, plus double money including the returned silver.

actuality.normalized: Israel resigned himself to possible bereavement of his children.
The brothers took the present, double money, and Benjamin; they went down to Egypt and stood before Joseph.
Seeing Benjamin, Joseph ordered his steward to bring the men to his house and prepare a noon meal.
The steward did as instructed and brought the men into Joseph’s house.
Fearing accusation over the money in their sacks, the brothers suspected a pretext to enslave them and seize their donkeys.
At the door they explained to the steward about finding their money at the lodging-place, returning it, and bringing other money to buy food.
The steward reassured them, attributing the treasure to their God, affirmed he had received their payment, and brought Simeon out.
They were received in Joseph’s house with water for washing and feed for their donkeys.
They prepared their present, expecting to eat bread there at noon.
When Joseph arrived home, they presented the gift and bowed themselves to the earth.
Joseph asked after their welfare and their father; they replied that their father, his servant, was alive and well, and again bowed.
Joseph blessed Benjamin, calling for God’s grace upon him.
Overcome with yearning for Benjamin, Joseph withdrew to weep, then washed his face and restrained himself.
Separate tables were set for Joseph, for his brothers, and for the Egyptians, since Egyptians would not eat with Hebrews as it was an abomination.
They were seated by birth order from firstborn to youngest, which caused them to marvel.
Served portions from before Joseph, Benjamin received a portion five times larger; they drank and were merry with him.
Joseph ordered the steward to fill their sacks with food, return each man’s money, and place his silver goblet in Benjamin’s sack; the steward obeyed.
At daybreak the men were sent away with their donkeys.
Joseph sent his steward to overtake and accuse them of repaying good with evil by stealing the divining cup.
They denied the charge, citing their honesty in returning the earlier money.
They rashly proposed that whoever had the cup should die and the rest become bondmen.
The steward moderated the sentence: only the one with whom the goblet was found would be his bondman; the others would be blameless.
A search from eldest to youngest revealed the goblet in Benjamin’s sack.
They tore their clothes, reloaded their donkeys, and returned to the city.
Judah and his brothers fell before Joseph when they reached his house.
Joseph rebuked them, asserting that a man like him would indeed divine.
Judah confessed inability to justify themselves, attributing discovery of their iniquity to God, and offered that all become Joseph’s bondmen including the one with the cup.
Joseph refused collective punishment and demanded only the man with the goblet be his bondman, sending the others back in peace.
Judah approached and petitioned to speak, acknowledging Joseph’s authority as like Pharaoh’s.
Judah recounted Joseph’s inquiry about their family, stating they had an aged father and a youngest son whose brother was dead and who alone remained of his mother, loved by his father.
Judah recalled Joseph’s demand to bring the lad, their warning that the lad could not leave his father lest he die, and Joseph’s insistence they would not see his face otherwise.
Judah explained they reported the terms to their father who later told them to buy food; they answered that they could not go without the youngest.
Judah quoted his father saying that his wife bore him two sons.

entity.description: House manager who executed Joseph’s orders, reassured the brothers, released Simeon, hosted them, and conducted the search.
Joseph’s cup placed in Benjamin’s sack and invoked as a divining cup; its discovery triggered the crisis.
Custom that Egyptians would not eat bread with Hebrews, considered an abomination.
Benjamin was given a serving five times larger than his brothers during the meal.

actuality.normalized: Jacob’s prior words recounted: one son went out and was presumed torn; if Benjamin is taken and harmed, Jacob’s gray hairs would be brought down with sorrow to the grave.
Judah argued that Jacob’s soul is bound up with the lad; if Benjamin does not return, Jacob will die and they will bring down their father’s gray hairs with sorrow to the grave.
Judah reaffirmed he became surety for the lad before his father and would bear the blame forever if he failed.
Judah offered himself to remain as bondman in place of the lad and asked that Benjamin be allowed to go up with his brothers.
Judah concluded he could not face his father without the lad, lest he see the evil that would befall his father.
Joseph could no longer restrain himself; he sent everyone out and revealed himself to his brothers.
Joseph wept aloud so that the Egyptians and Pharaoh’s household heard.
Joseph said, “I am Joseph; does my father still live?” His brothers were unable to answer, being terrified at his presence.
Joseph invited them near and identified himself as the brother they sold into Egypt.
Joseph reassured them: do not be grieved or angry; God sent me ahead to preserve life; two years of famine have passed and five remain without plowing or harvest.
Joseph stated that God sent him to preserve a remnant and effect a great deliverance; God, not they, sent him and made him ‘a father to Pharaoh’ and ruler over Egypt.
Joseph commanded them to hasten to Jacob with the message of his rule and to bring him down without delay.
Joseph promised they would dwell near him in the land of Goshen with all their households and possessions.
He pledged to sustain them through the remaining five years of famine to prevent their impoverishment.
Joseph emphasized authenticity—his own mouth speaking—and urged them to tell his glory in Egypt and hasten to bring Jacob down.
Joseph and Benjamin wept upon each other’s neck; Joseph kissed all his brothers and wept, after which they talked with him.
News reached Pharaoh; it pleased Pharaoh and his servants.
Pharaoh ordered Joseph to send his brothers to bring their father and households from Canaan, promising the good of Egypt and its fat.
Pharaoh commanded that wagons be taken for the little ones and wives and for Jacob to be brought down; they were not to regard their stuff.
The sons of Israel did so; Joseph gave them wagons per Pharaoh’s command and provisions for the way.
Joseph gave each brother changes of raiment; Benjamin received three hundred shekels of silver and five changes of raiment.
He sent to his father ten asses with Egypt’s good things and ten she-asses with grain, bread, and victuals.
He sent his brothers away with the admonition, 'See that you do not quarrel on the way.'
They reported to Jacob that Joseph was alive and ruler over Egypt; he initially disbelieved and his heart fainted.
Upon hearing Joseph’s words and seeing the wagons he sent, Jacob’s spirit revived; Israel resolved to go and see Joseph before he died.
Israel journeyed to Beer-sheba and offered sacrifices to the God of his father Isaac.

God spoke to Israel in night visions, calling 'Jacob, Jacob'; He identified Himself, told him not to fear going down to Egypt, promised to make him a great nation there, to go down and bring him up again, and that Joseph would close his eyes.
Jacob rose from Beer-sheba; his sons carried him, their children, and their wives in the wagons Pharaoh sent, taking their cattle and goods into Egypt—all his seed with him.
His sons, grandsons, daughters, and granddaughters—all his descendants—entered Egypt with him.
The genealogy begins listing the children of Israel who came into Egypt: Jacob and his sons, starting with Reuben and the names of Reuben’s and Simeon’s sons.

participants.subject_reference: Reuben and Simeon and their sons

entity.description: District in Egypt where Joseph planned for Jacob and his household to dwell near him.
Carts provided by Pharaoh for transporting Jacob’s family and belongings to Egypt; seeing them revived Jacob’s spirit.
Israel’s offerings to the God of his father Isaac at Beer-sheba before descending to Egypt.

actuality.normalized: The sons of Levi were Gershon, Kohath, and Merari.
The sons of Judah were Er, Onan, Shelah, Perez, and Zerah; Er and Onan died in Canaan. The sons of Perez were Hezron and Hamul.
The sons of Issachar were Tola, Puvah, Iob, and Shimron.
The sons of Zebulun were Sered, Elon, and Jahleel.
These are the children of Leah (including Dinah) whom she bore to Jacob in Paddan-aram; all the persons of his sons and daughters were thirty-three.
The sons of Gad were Ziphion, Haggi, Shuni, Ezbon, Eri, Arodi, and Areli.

participants.subject_reference: Ziphion, Haggi, Shuni, Ezbon, Eri, Arodi, Areli

actuality.normalized: The sons of Asher were Imnah, Ishvah, Ishvi, Beriah, and their sister Serah; Beriah’s sons were Heber and Malchiel.
These are the sons of Zilpah (Laban gave her to Leah) whom she bore to Jacob—sixteen persons.
The sons of Rachel, Jacob’s wife, were Joseph and Benjamin.
In Egypt, Joseph’s sons born to him by Asenath daughter of Poti-phera priest of On were Manasseh and Ephraim.
The sons of Benjamin were Bela, Becher, Ashbel, Gera, Naaman, Ehi, Rosh, Muppim, Huppim, and Ard.

participants.subject_reference: Bela, Becher, Ashbel, Gera, Naaman, Ehi, Rosh, Muppim, Huppim, Ard

actuality.normalized: These are the sons of Rachel who were born to Jacob—fourteen persons in all.
The sons of Dan: Hushim.
The sons of Naphtali were Jahzeel, Guni, Jezer, and Shillem.
These are the sons of Bilhah (whom Laban gave to Rachel) whom she bore to Jacob—seven persons.
All the persons belonging to Jacob who came into Egypt from his loins, excluding the wives of his sons, were sixty-six.
The sons of Joseph born in Egypt were two; all the persons of Jacob’s house who came into Egypt were seventy.
Judah was sent ahead to Joseph to show the way to Goshen; they arrived in the land of Goshen.
Joseph prepared his chariot, went up to meet Israel in Goshen, presented himself, fell on his father’s neck, and wept a long while.
Israel said to Joseph: 'Now let me die, since I have seen your face and you are still alive.'

Joseph planned to inform Pharaoh that his family, keepers of cattle, had come with their flocks and herds; he instructed them to identify as keepers of cattle so they might dwell in Goshen, for every shepherd is an abomination to the Egyptians.

Joseph informed Pharaoh of his family’s arrival in Goshen and presented five of his brothers; they declared their occupation as shepherds and requested to sojourn in Goshen due to severe famine in Canaan. Pharaoh authorized them to dwell in the best of the land, in Goshen, and invited Joseph to appoint any able men over Pharaoh’s cattle.
Joseph brought in Jacob before Pharaoh; Jacob blessed Pharaoh, answered that his sojournings were 130 years—few and hard compared to his fathers—and blessed Pharaoh again before departing.

Joseph settled his father and brothers, granting them a possession in Egypt’s best land, in the land of Rameses, as Pharaoh commanded; he supplied his father’s household with bread proportionate to dependents.
There was no bread in all the land; the famine was very severe and both Egypt and Canaan languished.
Joseph collected all the money in Egypt and Canaan in exchange for grain and brought the money into Pharaoh’s house.
When the money was spent, Joseph exchanged bread for livestock—horses, flocks, herds, and asses—feeding the people that year.
The next year the people, having no money or cattle, offered their bodies and their land to Pharaoh for bread and seed so they might live and the land not be desolate.
Joseph bought all the land of Egypt for Pharaoh because of the severe famine; the land became Pharaoh’s.
Joseph relocated the people city by city across Egypt from one end to the other.

entity.description: Designation for the best part of Egypt where Jacob’s family received a possession.
Cultural norm noted by Joseph: every shepherd is an abomination to the Egyptians, leveraged to situate Israel in Goshen.

actuality.normalized: Joseph did not purchase the priests’ land because they had a portion from Pharaoh and thus did not sell their land.
Joseph told the people he had bought them and their land for Pharaoh, gave them seed to sow, and instituted a fifth of the ingathering for Pharaoh with four parts for seed and household food.
The people affirmed Joseph had saved their lives and submitted to be Pharaoh’s bondmen; Joseph made the fifth a statute in Egypt, except for the priests’ land.
Israel dwelt in Goshen, acquired possessions, and multiplied exceedingly.
Jacob lived in Egypt seventeen years; his total age was 147 years.
Jacob charged Joseph to swear to bury him with his fathers in their burial place, not in Egypt; Joseph swore, and Israel bowed upon the bed’s head.
When told that Jacob was sick, Joseph came with Manasseh and Ephraim; Israel strengthened himself and sat upon the bed.
Jacob recounted God Almighty’s appearance at Luz/Canaan and the promise of fruitfulness and everlasting possession of the land to his seed.
Jacob adopted Joseph’s two sons born in Egypt—Ephraim and Manasseh—as his own, like Reuben and Simeon; later issue would be counted under their brothers’ names.
Jacob recalled Rachel’s death and burial on the way to Ephrath (Bethlehem).
Israel recognized and embraced the boys, asked who they were, and requested Joseph to bring them for blessing; his eyesight was dim.
Joseph positioned Manasseh at Israel’s right and Ephraim at his left, but Israel crossed his hands, placing his right on Ephraim (the younger) and left on Manasseh.
Jacob blessed Joseph’s sons, invoking the God of his fathers and the angel who redeemed him, that the lads be blessed, bear his and his fathers’ names, and grow into a multitude in the earth.

Joseph objected to the right hand on Ephraim, but Jacob refused, declaring both would be great, yet the younger would be greater; he set Ephraim before Manasseh and fixed the blessing formula for Israel: “God make thee as Ephraim and as Manasseh.”
Israel told Joseph that God would be with them and bring them back to their fathers’ land, granting Joseph one portion above his brothers, taken from the Amorite with sword and bow.
Jacob summoned his sons to tell what would befall them in the end of days and called them to assemble and listen.
Reuben, Jacob’s firstborn and strength, forfeits excellency for instability and defiling his father’s bed.
Simeon and Levi are condemned for violent wrath; Jacob curses their anger and declares they will be divided and scattered in Israel.

Judah is praised; his hand will be on his enemies’ neck and his brothers will bow to him. The scepter will not depart from Judah nor the ruler’s staff from between his feet until Shiloh comes; to him the peoples’ obedience shall be. (Vine/foal imagery begins.)

entity.description: A standing law in Egypt established by Joseph: one-fifth of produce belongs to Pharaoh; priests’ land exempt.
Royal provision allotted to Egyptian priests, preserving their land from sale.
Jacob’s intentional reversal of primogeniture by crossing hands, preferring Ephraim over firstborn Manasseh.
Term in Judah’s oracle associated with the endurance of the scepter and coming obedience of peoples.

actuality.normalized: Judah’s abundance is pictured as washing garments in wine and vesture in the blood of grapes; his eyes are red from wine and his teeth white with milk.
Zebulun will dwell by the sea, be a haven for ships, with his flank toward Sidon.
Issachar, likened to a strong donkey resting among folds, prefers pleasant land and submits to forced labor.
Dan will judge his people as a tribe of Israel and will be like a serpent on the path striking the horse’s heels.
Jacob interjects a prayer: 'I wait for Your salvation, O LORD.'
Gad will be raided by a raiding party, but he will raid at their heels.
Asher’s food will be rich; he will yield royal delicacies.
Naphtali is a hind let loose who gives beautiful words.

Joseph is a fruitful vine by a spring whose branches climb over a wall; though attacked by archers, his bow remains firm by the Mighty One of Jacob—from the Shepherd, the Stone of Israel—who blesses him.

participants.subject_reference: Mighty One of Jacob / Shepherd / Stone of Israel

actuality.normalized: Joseph receives blessings of heaven above, the deep below, and of breasts and womb; Jacob’s blessings surpass his ancestors up to the everlasting hills, resting on Joseph’s head, the prince among his brothers.
Benjamin is a ravenous wolf: in the morning devouring prey and at evening dividing spoil.
These are the twelve tribes of Israel; their father spoke to and blessed each one according to his blessing.

Jacob charged his sons to bury him with his fathers in the cave of Machpelah before Mamre, in Canaan, which Abraham purchased from Ephron the Hittite; there Abraham and Sarah, Isaac and Rebekah, and Leah are buried.

participants.subject_reference: Cave of Machpelah / Ephron the Hittite

actuality.normalized: Jacob finished commanding his sons, gathered his feet into the bed, expired, and was gathered to his people.
Joseph wept over his father, kissed him, and ordered the physicians to embalm Israel; forty days were fulfilled for embalming, and the Egyptians mourned seventy days.
Joseph requested Pharaoh’s leave to bury his father in Canaan as sworn; Pharaoh consented.
A very great company—Pharaoh’s servants, elders of his house and of Egypt, with chariots and horsemen—went up with Joseph; households remained in Goshen.
At the threshing-floor of Atad beyond the Jordan, they held seven days of intense mourning; locals called the place Abel-mizraim.
Jacob’s sons buried him in the cave of the field of Machpelah as commanded and returned to Egypt.

Fearing Joseph’s vengeance after Jacob’s death, the brothers sought forgiveness in their father’s name and offered themselves as bondmen; Joseph wept and reassured them, affirming God turned their intended evil to good to save many and promising to sustain them and their little ones.
Joseph dwelt in Egypt and lived 110 years, seeing Ephraim’s children to the third generation and Machir son of Manasseh’s children born on his knees.
Before dying, Joseph declared God would surely remember Israel and bring them up to the sworn land, and he bound the children of Israel by oath to carry up his bones.
Joseph died at 110, was embalmed, and placed in a coffin in Egypt.

entity.description: Family burial cave before Mamre in Canaan, purchased by Abraham from Ephron the Hittite; burial site of Abraham/Sarah, Isaac/Rebekah, Leah, and later Jacob.
Site beyond the Jordan where seven days of great mourning were held for Jacob; named by Canaanites ‘Abel-mizraim’ (Egyptian mourning).
Forty days for embalming and seventy days of Egyptian mourning observed for Jacob.
